Ken,

   One troubling "detail" is that of differences in dimensionality 
b=
etween substrate inputs and outputs. In the examples used in the 
various p=
apers, the dimensionality of the substrate input and output 
nodes, as appl=
ied to the Hypercube inputs, were identical (i.e. x_in, 
y_in, x_out, y_out=
). This simplifies the concept of distance. But the 
problem could just as =
easily have been: Do the two squares on the 
visual field overlap? (yes/no)=
. In this case, dimensionality of the 
substrate input and output nodes, as=
 applied to the Hypercube inputs, 
have differing dimensionality, even thou=
gh the answer is strongly 
dependent on proximity in the input visual field=
. Any experience or 
comments on this seemly more common general condition?=


Thanks,
   Andy Carl 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <ks=
tanley@...> wrote:
>
> Andy, I'd say this is a about right.  I elaborate a =
bit below each 
> part of your question:
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
"afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> >
> > Jason or Ken,
> > 
> >    I am attemptin=
g to understand the nature of inputs & outputs 
as 
> > applied to both the=
 Hypercube and substrate networks, without 
being 
> > limited to the geome=
tric nature of the visual-based examples. The 
> > examples provided were h=
elpful, but I am striving for a more 
> general 
> > guideline for applicat=
ion to more general problems.
> > 
> >    Would it be correct to say that:
=
> > 
> > (a) Substrate Network: Inputs & Outputs identified as typical to 
=
> > application of conventional NEAT to a problem of interest;
> > 
> 
> Th=
is statement is correct although you might do things that you 
would 
> avo=
id doing in conventional NEAT because HyperNEAT can deal with so 
> many mo=
re inputs and outputs.  So you might for example output a 
high 
> resoluti=
on representation of your possible decisions, which is 
> something you nor=
mally wouldn't do in regular NEAT.
> 
> > (b) Hypercube Network: (i) Inputs=
: Other descriptors/parameters 
> (i.e. 
> > geometric coordinates being a =
subset thereof), associated with a 
> given 
> > substrate network node (i.=
e. like a timestamp associated with a 
> > coordinate point comprising a tr=
ajectory), mutually exclusive of 
> the 
> > descriptor/parameter expressly=
 identified in the substrate node, 
> each 
> > being collected together an=
d collectively identified as either 
> a "from" 
> > or "to" terminator of =
a link between any two substrate nodes; and 
> (ii) 
> > Output: Weight of =
link between the currently identified "from" 
> and "to" 
> > substrate nod=
es.
> > 
> 
> I think this characterizes it well, although there is even mo=
re 
> flexibility.  You can for example use additional outputs on the 
CPPN=
 
> to represent additional attributes of links and/or nodes.  
> 
> The ti=
mestamp idea is interesting- if I understand correctly it 
would 
> cause t=
he network to change over time in a deterministic way.  
> Although maybe I=
'm misunderstanding.  But certainly things like 
that 
> are possible.  
> =

> It's difficult to write an accurate general description of exactly 
> wh=
at goes in and comes out of the CPPN at this point because I have 
> no dou=
bt that at this early stage that new ideas are going to 
broaden 
> the pos=
sibilities beyond what I am currently aware of.   But what 
you 
> said cap=
tures it pretty well for now.
> 
> ken
>
